image.altText: A man and a woman inside a camper van.

props.synopsis: Northern Territory police have announced a new $500,000 reward for information that leads to the discovery of Peter Falconio's body, more than 20 years after his murder.

title.children: Police offer $500k reward in bid to find Peter Falconio's remains

image.altText: A full street with people marching with flags and signs, one says: liberation freedom restitution.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been urged to convene national cabinet to address First Nations deaths in custody and incarceration, as justice leaders, experts and community voices meet today in Alice Springs.

title.children: First Nations leaders urge PM to convene national cabinet on prison crisis

image.altText: Andrew Hastie sits for an interview in a room. He has a serious expression.

props.synopsis: The Coalition frontbencher is also urging the Labor government explain what role Australia might play backing US combat operations launched from this country.

title.children: Hastie demands answer about US military's growing presence in Australia

image.altText: Two people in a car.

props.synopsis: Finke Desert Race co-driver Bernie Webb says a safety mechanism kept him and his driver safe after they lost control at 160kph.

title.children: Desert racers release cabin video of high-speed, airborne crash

image.altText: Two men in suits sit behind a desk speaking and laughing with each other

props.synopsis: The meeting of world leaders at The Hague resulted in a spending increase for most European members of NATO, but it was the US president that once again set the tone.

title.children: NATO chief calls Trump 'daddy' at summit that sees Europe's defence spending increase

image.altText: An image of Erin Patterson.

props.synopsis: The judge in Erin Patterson's triple-murder trial is continuing to deliver his final instructions to the jury. Ms Patterson is accused of deliberately poisoning her relatives by serving them a meal containing death cap mushrooms. Follow the proceedings live.

title.children: Judge continues instructions for jury in Erin Patterson triple-murder trial

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Ms Patterson's reluctance to receive treatment
Turning now to the children's medical treatment
Jury told to disregard suggestion children would be sick from leftovers

image.altText: Tucker Carlson speaks into a microphone at a podium.

props.synopsis: Former Fox News host Tucker Carlson says the network's Australian boss, Lachlan Murdoch, encouraged him to run for US president to thwart Donald Trump's return to the White House.

title.children: 'The Murdochs really hate Trump': Carlson says Fox CEO urged election run

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: Australian stocks are lower, while oil prices are rising, snapping three straight sessions of losses. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX falls, ACCC sues Australian Gas over 'greenwashing'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: 'We are disappointed': Gas group responds to ACCC court action
Job vacancies rise 2.9% in three months to May
Share market lower at lunch time, Xero falls

image.altText: Two policemen watch as a yellow crane truck lifts a metal box in grassland.

props.synopsis: Trent Thrupp, Stou Daniels and Davy Taiao have been sentenced after they were again found guilty of the 2016 murders of Iuliana Triscaru and Cory Breton.

title.children: Men sentenced to life in jail over 'cruel deaths' again after retrial

image.altText: A woman embraces a group of people outside court

props.synopsis: On Wednesday, the Federal Court ruled that Antoinette Lattouf was unlawfully terminated by the ABC in December 2023. This is what we know about what will happen next.

title.children: Why the Lattouf v ABC legal saga isn't over yet

image.altText: Queensland cricketer Usman Khawaja looks at a questioner during a press conference after a Sheffield Shield game.

props.synopsis: Usman Khawaja refuses to speak to radio broadcaster SEN on day one of the first Test against the West Indies, reportedly over the network's decision to axe Peter Lalor earlier this year.

title.children: Khawaja refuses radio interview after SEN axes journalist over Gaza posts

image.altText: And older woman with sore and tired eyes, using a smartphone while lying in bed late at night.

props.synopsis: From digital detox bootcamps to 12-step programs, a range of treatments exist for problematic internet use. So why is internet addiction disorder not yet an official psychological diagnosis?

title.children: Internet overuse isn't an official addiction, but it's treated as one

image.altText: Josh Inglis crouches down

props.synopsis: The more things change, the more they stay the same, as Australia's reshuffled top order fails and old faithful Usman Khawaja and Travis Head rescue the tourists' blushes.

title.children: Same old saviours rescue Aussies after 'woeful' top-order batting

image.altText: Watercolour illustration of aboriginal child riding a 44 gallon drum tied between two trees.

props.synopsis: Young stockman Wylie Oscar went missing in outback Western Australia three years ago. His case remains a mystery

title.children: Wylie Oscar left a friend's house in 2022. He hasn't been seen since

image.altText: A man runs past a creek on a rural property.

props.synopsis: Endurance athlete Phil Gore has broken the Backyard Ultra world record with a 797-kilometre run at Dead Cow Gully in Queensland.

title.children: Aussie sets world record with 800km run in five days

image.altText: An adult white woman with long blonde hair and a black coat standing in front of a power point presentation

props.synopsis: New resources launched by Australia's Education Research Organisation will arm all teachers with the skills to teach writing.

title.children: 'Wasn't part of the syllabus': Australia's 30-year failure in teaching writing

image.altText: A female doctor carrying a stethoscope.

props.synopsis: Medical students say a rural work program meant to solve doctor shortages is pushing some to abandon their careers and others to pay their way out of the scheme.

title.children: Medical graduates question rural relocation work scheme

image.altText: Miley Cyrus stands for a photo wearing a black, silver and purple dress with houses and trees below her in the background.

props.synopsis: Unable to tour for health reasons, Miley Cyrus has made a visual album she has described as similar to Pink Floyd's The Wall, but "with a better wardrobe".

title.children: Miley Cyrus can't tour anymore, so she made a one-night cinema spectacular

image.altText: Aerial view of cleared land

props.synopsis: A Victorian sawmill has harvested wood from endangered mountain ash forests and sold it to Domino's as woodchips to smoke meat for pizzas.

title.children: Domino's pizzas allegedly cooked using woodchips from endangered possum habitat

image.altText: A man walks down some steps. He has his hands in his pockets.

props.synopsis: A serial rapist who attempted to abduct a teenage girl to rape her 45 years ago has avoided jail time.

title.children: Serial rapist who tried to abduct teen for sex avoids more jail

image.altText: A young girl with red hair tucked into bed, lying on her side and blowing her nose.

props.synopsis: Winter can be a contagious time of year for everything from COVID-19 to the common cold, but there are ways to limit the risk of illnesses spreading from one family member or housemate to another.

title.children: What you can do to stop the spread of illness in your home

image.altText: Two people walk past an yellow conversion rate sign

props.synopsis: The US Treasury has imposed sanctions on three Mexican financial institutions, accusing them of laundering millions of dollars for cartels involved in getting fentanyl into the US.

title.children: US sanctions Mexican banks for allegedly laundering money for drug cartels

image.altText: Aboriginal girl sitting in her garden and smiling

props.synopsis: With their hometown long troubled by youth crime, the children of Halls Creek have some clear ideas about what the community needs.

title.children: Outback kids back their town to find a solution to its troubles

image.altText: women wearing religious clothing and waving Iranian flags.

props.synopsis: Despite a ceasefire being declared between Israel, the United States and Iran, we're now "moving into a true danger zone", some analysts say, because the Islamic Republic is now trying to develop a nuclear weapon faster than ever.

title.children: Despite Israel-Iran ceasefire, some analysts say we're moving into a 'danger zone'

image.altText: A temporary fence with police tape on it.

props.synopsis: Residents forced to abandon their homes after a landslip in Newcastle last month have been left feeling "helpless", with several of the unoccupied homes looted in recent weeks.

title.children: Looters swoop as landslip forces 'helpless' residents from their homes

image.altText: Silver gas pipelines run along ground with trees behidn them

props.synopsis: Australian households are using less gas, with some getting off the fuel entirely. And that changes the whole business model for gas pipelines in a way that could see consumers paying more.

title.children: As gas use declines, those remaining could foot bigger bills

image.altText: A sign on a brick wall reads 'Western Sydney University', in the distance are some large buildings.

props.synopsis: The Australian Sanctions Office has investigated an event held on the campus of Western Sydney University as possibly breaching sanctions placed on PressTV, Iran's state media outlet.

title.children: Uni cops sanctions warning after Iran state media attended event on campus

image.altText: A family looks out onto planes on the tarmac at an airport.

props.synopsis: In the days after the Air India crash, it was revealed that warnings had been issued about some of the airline's other planes. So, why isn't information like this always publicly available? And how can we know which airlines are safe?

title.children: What's the safest airline, and why the answer might not be straightforward

image.altText: Tara sits with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: ACT Attorney-General Tara Cheyne sat through a debate about a motion on women's safety quietly, thinking she wouldn't speak. But then she stood up with conviction and spoke about an incident she'd never talked about before.

title.children: Tara Cheyne reveals stranger sexually assaulted her in broad daylight

image.altText: Former student arrested over WSU hacks

props.synopsis: Police believe a former Western Sydney University student allegedly escalated from hacking into the uni's servers for free parking to threatening the sale of her peers' data on the dark web.

title.children: Ex-student hacked uni for free parking before threatening data drop, police say

image.altText: Two men in suits hold a framed wooden fish in front of a wood-panelled wall

props.synopsis: Australia will provide sweeping support for Solomon Islands ahead of a key leaders meeting in September.

title.children: Australia to provide $20 million package to Solomon Islands for key forum

image.altText: A tub of Mundella Foods yoghurt.

props.synopsis: The family-owned WA dairy processor is in trouble with trio of companies facing insolvency, and employees and suppliers claiming they are owed thousands of dollars in bills and superannuation.

title.children: Mundella workers, suppliers owed thousands as administrators take over

image.altText: Woman with blond hair and black shirt standing in front of house

props.synopsis: Montana Adams lost everything in a horrific house fire. Her landlord tried to claim $15,000 in compensation after accusing her of starting it.

title.children: Mother of eight blamed by landlord for accidental fire that gutted house
